question: Is the city's transportation designed for emergency preparedness?
Will there be tunnels under the city and skywalks to avoid the weather?
What if it wasn't just about Boston, but all towns and all people, including those nowhere near the T or the commuter rail or the Bloom charter bus company?
Will rails to trails turn into trails to rails?

We need a circle line or bus(express) that connects the subway lines together. The lines are designed so that you have to go in and back out which is very limited. The London subway system look almost identical to our except that they have a circle line.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/travel/downloads/tube_map.gif

How will Boston ensure that seniors and persons with disabilities receive the extra supports that are crucial to their accessing transportation (i.e. support before pick-up or after drop off to ensure they are able to move through buildings as well as across the city)?

The transportation available this week was miserable, at best. It did not matter if you chose bus, T, Commuter Rail, or car! The Governor and Mayor did not consider people with childcare issues, or disabled when providing transportation this week.  The decisions to close places were wishy washy!  The Governor and Mayor need to be more assertive to the universities and companies so that the snow can be cleared!
How can we ensure funding for these incredibly vital improvements to our infrastructure?
How can we get more cycle tracks in the city?
As our population ages, how will we accommodate their needs?
Will the Old Northern Avenue Bridge be a pedestrian bridge?
In the future, could MBTA vehicles increase seating capacity?
Will sidewalks in Chinatown and downtown be smoother?
Is there a more efficient way to allow Green Line passengers to pay their fare before boarding the train above ground?  For example, have a pay station on the street.
